Allan,

I tried this already too. The problem is not in JUnit being exported 
from VAJ. The problem is in the method call to inVAJava() from JUnit.
That method only returns true if it can execute
Class.forName("com.ibm.uvm.tools.DebugSupport");  
The only time it can execute the above line, is when there are native 
IBM Java classes available, specificaly uvmtools in java.library.path.
I have exported all the native classes into a jar file and run the 
program with the native jars in the classpath. It cannot find the 
linking class to DebugSupport.

Could it have anything to do with the SDK version?
I'm using 1.2

Thanks,

Lily


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Alan C Francis" <listsub@t...> wrote:
> > I tried your suggestion but it still doesn't run. inVAJava() 
checks
> > for Class.forName("com.ibm.uvm.tools.DebugSupport");  and since 
this
> > class has to be linked with another ibm java class, it throws the
> > same LinkageError: java.jang.UnsatistiedLinkError:no uvmtools in
> > java.library.path
> 
> I can assure you that many thousands of us run junit every day with 
no VAJ.
> 
> You can download junit.zip from junit.org.
> 
> Unzip this into a directory.
> 
> Ensure that the junit.jar file you just unzipped is on your 
classpath BEFORE
> any VAJ directories.
> 
> run
> 
> java -cp /path/to/junit.jar;%CLASSPATH% junit.ui.TestRunner
> 
> All will be well.  The inVAJava() is used for weird classloading 
purposes,
> not for any 'security' reason.  I'm not sure its even in the 
codebase any
> more.
> 
> A.

> agile is not a synonym for good
